awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Adaptable Ad Hoc Network Architecture for Rapid Infrastructure Development in Disaster Zones
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is reducing the cost of getting people online and connecting people in emergency situations such as natural disasters. Natural disasters often destroy cellular networks, exactly when people need communication the most. The influx of users on the limited remaining infrastructure often overwhelms existing resources, making it impossible for first responders to coordinate, for families to call their loved ones, and for volunteers to help. In other potential markets, the technology seeks to provide cellular phone access to parts of the world where it is now prohibitively expensive. This project seeks to develop small, portable cellular base stations that can provide access in both emergency and hard to reach and poorly resourced locations.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project researches and implements a small, portable cellular base station. The technological focus for the base station utilizes Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) / General Packet Radio Service (GPRS) (or 2G and 2.5G) radio for communicating with a high density of cell phones in a computationally cheap manner while utilizing WiFi for local, high bandwidth applications. The technology implements many “micro-cells” in lieu of the current macro cell approach to cellular coverage, blanketing the area with a high number of towers. This decentralized approach provides high reliability even if one or several nodes fail. This project will develop the algorithms necessary for interconnecting large numbers of base stations together and mesh the networking capabilities that provide radio links between each base station. Finally, this project will finalize the mechanical design and make the base station manufacturable at large scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Beamlink developed an adaptable ad-hoc mesh network cellular network that can be rapidly deployed for disaster response and emergency purposes through this NSF award. The architecture was designed to provide network users with 4G LTE and WiFi coverage to personal devices, computers, and IoT devices. Each “base station” (or individual radio unit which provided coverage) was interlinked via an 802.11 mesh network. The goal was to reduce requirements for backhaul (or an external connection to the Internet via satellite receiver) to less than 25% of the base stations. Beamlink achieved this in field testing performed at the JIFX 23-2 field test and in the Mojave desert at Beamlink’s test site.

Beamlink takes a “Raspberry Pi” approach to cellular networks: reducing cost, weight, size, and power (and increasing ease of use) for 5G technology. New work in software-defined radio and mobile computing architecture allows flexibility in using hardware across different countries; mobile-first computing condenses servers to a smaller form factor, lower heat output and power consumption, and moves unnecessary features to the cloud. 

Typical hardware for modern 5G networks is designed for use in server racks, air-conditioned with generators and ample space for the equipment required to run a large cell tower. The tower itself contains millions of dollars of antennas, tower-top amplifiers, and other RF equipment. Billions of dollars of R&D has led to cutting edge improvements in latency, user capacity, and 5G system interoperability.

Beamlink conducted R&D in software-defined radio hardware, embedded and cloud software, mechanical engineering, and cooling systems to re-engineer cellular base station hardware from server racks to “lunch-box sized”. Beamlink demonstrated designs of cellular base stations capable of 4G/5G communications up to 80 Mbps to smartphone devices, with <50W power requirements, <5 lbs weight, and no external hardware operation requirements. Beamlink demonstrated interoperability with any source of internet connectivity, even SpaceX’s new Starlink constellation, and interoperability with any user device, including devices from Google, Samsung, and Apple with physical sim cards and eSims providing easy process to join private networks, with up to 9 devices simultaneously transmitting gigabytes of data during stress testing, proving the architecture viable.  Beamlink “emulated” several different configurations of devices through software, finding that at a distance of 275m emulated between base stations, average latency due to mesh links is 50.4 ms with a 20 node configuration in-line and 7.9 ms with 4 nodes in-line over air. The team measured a 50.6% decrease in link speed over 4 nodes and 57.5% decrease in link speed over 20 nodes (where link speed is the maximum date rate packets can be transferred over the network). Each node adds 2.5 ms of latency on average when factoring over-the-air delay, on-board processing, and retransmission delays. In physical tests, there was an average latency of 0.8 ms and 6.4 mbps link speed when nodes are closeby (<3m). Beamlink pursued commercialization of the technologies aggressively by participating in the NSF Beat the Odds Bootcamp and NSF SBIR I-Corps program, conducting 130+ discovery interviews and attending 6 conferences.

Broader impacts relate to disaster relief and rural broadband: since 1980, 336 major disasters in the United States have caused $2.3 trillion in damage and over 15,000 deaths. Hurricane Maria in 2017 caused a record breaking $91.0 billion in damages in Puerto Rico and countless lives lost, with 95.2% of Puerto Rico cell sites out of service. While cell providers and the FCC worked to restore connectivity, cellular infrastructure remained damaged for over a year in rural areas. Beamlink’s NSF Research addresses the root cause of disaster relief connectivity: allowing businesses to operate, communities to organize, and first responders to coordinate. Beamlink provides high-speed radio access network technology in a low-cost, rapidly deployable package.

This technology clearly improves rural broadband access. The  Census Bureau says over 12% of American households still lack Internet. In rural areas, nearly one-fourth of the population (14.5 million) lacks access to fixed broadband–in tribal areas, nearly one-third. Communities of color disproportionately lack access to computers and Internet, too–broadband is an equity issue. With low-cost cellular base stations that do not require engineers to configure, costs to expand network connectivity dramatically decreases. Typical LTE /5G radio networks take 8-12 months to establish due to surveying, permits, and installation. Beamlink’s research demonstrated a time-to-first-packet-sent of less than 5 minutes. 

Beamlink is disseminating research results to communities outside wireless/cellular research (e.g. disaster relief, government disaster management, emergency responders) through roundtables and conferences like Storm Expo, CalOes Mitigation, and APCO (Public Safety Communications) in California, Mobile World Congress in Spain, and Connected Americas in Texas. Beamlink also released software and hardware designs for low-cost cellular network testing equipment for evaluating and improving cellular networks on Github for scientific and engineering research.
